Tag: Jeff Russo

Book Review Tuesday (11/28/23) ‚Äì Hunger Makes the Wolf

Happy Tuesday, bibliophiles!

Hunger Makes the Wolf came on my radar when I was looking for more books with disability rep (as always), but I ended up buying it on my Kindle after my dad notified me that I had some unused Kindle points (thank you for reminding me!)‚Äîit was free with the points added on, so how could I resist? And while Hunger Makes the Wolf wasn‚Äôt perfect, it‚Äôs a ton of gunslinging, space-fantasy fun.

Enjoy this week‚Äôs review!

Hunger Makes the Wolf (The Ghost Wolves, #1) ‚Äì Alex Wells

Hob Ravani ekes out a living in the deserts of Tanegawa‚Äôs World, a planet owned by TransRifts‚Äîthe corporation who controls the market on interstellar travel in the whole galaxy. For 10 years, Hob has gotten by with the help of the Ghost Wolves, a group of bandits roaming the desert and finding money where they can. But when Hob discovers the body of Nick, the man who recruited her to join the Wolves, abandoned in the desert, she knows that she has to act before TransRifts discovers their operation‚Äîand discovers the powers that she‚Äôs kept hidden from sight.

TW/CW: murder, descriptions of injuries, descriptions of corpses, violence, loss of loved ones, human experimentation

Writing accents phonetically is a slippery slope that I‚Äôm not going to get fully into in this review. In this case, though, Alex Wells had decent success with making everyone who was meant to sound like they had a Southern accent actually sound like they had a Southern accent, which worked‚Äîthis novel was a space Western, after all. That being said, the unintended consequence was that Wells‚Äô spelling of Hob‚Äôs accent was that I imagined her voice more like Holly Hunter in Raising Arizona than the badass, hardened gunslinger that she was made out to be. It sort of worked, though.

As far as sci-fi subgenres go, I‚Äôm not usually huge on space Westerns; I‚Äôve rarely seen them done exceedingly well (even The Mandalorian got more than a little repetitive eventually), but the best are at least fun. And that was what Hunger Makes the Wolf was‚Äîincredibly fun. It had all of the trappings of a debut novel, but what Wells did get right on the first time was that pacing. Although the action sequences were what made Hunger such a blast to read in the best parts, Wells also knew how to balance them out with quiet, more emotional moments, and also moments to slip in worldbuilding without absolutely walloping you with it. Wells‚Äô action was really the star of the show here; their fight scenes had just the right amount of tension, levity, and butt-kicking to make for more than one delightful scene.

Recently, I‚Äôve read several sci-fi books that were marketed as ‚Äúspace fantasy,‚Äù and none of them have really fit the bill. And yet, Hunger Makes the Wolf wasn‚Äôt necessarily marketed as such, but it does what the other novels lacked. Even amidst the classic sci-fi backdrop of corporate greed, massive spaceships, and gruesome human experimentation, there‚Äôs the element of the characters‚Äô strange hidden powers. Naming said powers ‚Äúwitchiness‚Äù was already a win in my book, the charm of it really fits the Western atmosphere that Wells was going for‚Äîit hits that sweet spot of not sounding overly jargon-y or formal, but not too hokey, either. Every time one of the characters mentioned it, I couldn‚Äôt help but smile‚Äîespecially in Hob‚Äôs aforementioned Holly Hunter voice.

Hunger Makes the Wolf is an incredibly ambitious novel, and the ambition is accentuated when you remember that this is Alex Wells‚Äô debut. In some ways, it worked; Wells managed to juggle a safe amount of the worldbuilding without leaving the reader without context, but also without dumping it excessively. However, what Wells did not juggle as well was the sheer amount of characters that we jump between. Hunger was clearly meant to have a found family theme to it, which I‚Äôm normally a sucker for, but Wells just had so many extraneous characters on their hands that none of the character relationships felt fleshed out. If we had gotten more scenes with Hob and the rest of the Wolves, for instance, I would have believed that they really were as thick as thieves. Adding onto this, the perspective switches may not have been necessary; Mags, although she plays a prominent role, doesn‚Äôt have a perspective or voice that added anything substantial to the narrative. It‚Äôs a classic debut author case: Alex Wells had some spot-on ideas, but they bit off far more than they could chew.

All in all, a rollicking space fantasy with action aplenty, but with characters that left me wanting more. 3.5 stars!

Hunger Makes the Wolf is the first book in the Ghost Wolves duology, followed by Blood Binds the Pack. Hunger was Alex Wells‚Äô debut novel; they are also the author of the short story Angel of the Blockade.

Goodreads Monday (7/12/21) ‚Äì Teen Killers Club

Happy Monday, bibliophiles!

Goodreads Monday is a weekly meme created by Lauren‚Äôs Page Turners. All you have to do to participate is pick a book from your Goodreads TBR, and explain why you want to read it.

Thrillers aren‚Äôt usually the kind of books that I readily pick up, but I‚Äôve found a few that I‚Äôve loved. And this one sounds fascinating ‚Äì unintentional found family and misfit assassins? Count me in!

Let‚Äôs begin, shall we?

GOODREADS MONDAY (7/12/21) ‚Äì TEEN KILLERS CLUB by Lily Sparks

Blurb from Goodreads:

Framed for the murder of her best friend, a young girl joins a super-secret society of teenage assassins to avoid a lifetime behind bars‚Äìand discovers her own true self‚Äìin this mesmerizing debut novel.

Seventeen-year-old Signal Deere has raised eyebrows for years as an unhappy Goth misfit from the trailer park. When she‚Äôs convicted of her best friend Rose‚Äôs brutal murder, she‚Äôs designated a Class A‚Äìthe most dangerous and manipulative criminal profile. To avoid prison, Signal signs on for a secret program for 18-and-under Class As and is whisked off to an abandoned sleep-away camp, where she and seven bunkmates will train as assassins. Yet even in the Teen Killers Club, Signal doesn‚Äôt fit in. She‚Äôs squeamish around blood. She‚Äôs kind and empathetic. And her optimistic attitude is threatening to turn a group of ragtag maniacs into a team of close-knit friends. Maybe that‚Äôs because Signal‚Äôs not really a killer. She was framed for Rose‚Äôs murder and only joined the program to escape, track down Rose‚Äôs real killer, and clear her name. But Signal never planned on the sinister technologies that keep the campers confined. She never planned on the mysterious man in the woods determined to pick them off one by one. And she certainly never planned on falling in love. Signal‚Äôs strategy is coming apart at the seams as the true killer prepares to strike again in Teen Killers Club.

So why do I want to read this?

OOOH‚Ä¶like I said, I‚Äôm not usually a thriller fan, but this sounds right up my alley‚Ä¶

Even though having protagonists with ‚ú®unique‚ú® names is a pet peeve of mine (‚Ä¶why would somebody name their child Signal?), I think I can look past it this time. (Maybe there‚Äôs a story behind it? We‚Äôll see‚Ä¶) Signal sounds like an intriguing character ‚Äì an outcast, framed for murder but with a tender heart, and determined to avenge her best friend.

And I LOVE the premise ‚Äì a bunch of teen assassins and criminals thrown together against their wills in an old summer camp. What could possibly go wrong? And the description‚Äôs hinting at both enemies-to-lovers and found family vibes ‚Äì two of my favorite tropes!

In short: I haven‚Äôt been this excited about a thriller since Before the Fall! (Then again, the two aren‚Äôt similar at all, so‚Ä¶)

Book Review Tuesday (1/5/21)‚ÄìAmong the Beasts & Briars

Happy Tuesday, bibliophiles! This is my last day before I have to go back to school‚Ä¶ so heads up, I‚Äôll probably be posting less frequently in the next few months because of school.

Anyway, this book was one of my most anticipated reads of 2020. Ashley Poston is one of my favorite authors, and I‚Äôll always hold her Heart of Iron duology close to my heart. And although Among the Beasts & Briars didn‚Äôt quite hit the level of wondrousness of that duology, it was still a fantasy like no other that I‚Äôll always cherish.

Enjoy the first book review Tuesday of the year!

Among the Beasts & Briars‚ÄìAshley Poston

Cerys leads a quiet life in the kingdom of Aloriya, working with her father to tend the royal gardens. But behind her life of peace is a haunted past‚Äìas a child, the woods surrounding her kingdom stole her friends and her mother. She has never seen them again since. But by some miracle, the woods left Cerys alone, marked only by traces of magic in her blood.

When the woods invade the coronation of Aloriya‚Äôs new queen, Cerys is forced to flee. Joined by a familiar fox who followed close behind her in the gardens and a bear hiding momentous secrets, she must journey to the heart of the woods, where it is said that an isolated town has escaped the curse that took her mother and friends. But the woods hold secrets darker than the three could ever know‚Ä¶

TW/CW (from Ashley Poston): Frightening Situations, Secondary Character Death, Trypophobia, Bleeding/Self-Harm (not suicidal), Animal Attack, Blood, Grotesque Transformations

I saw a fox outside my window this morning when I woke up‚Ä¶maybe it was a sign that today was the perfect day to write this review‚Ä¶

I think Among the Beasts & Briars was the last book I read this year, and I honestly can‚Äôt think of a better book that I could‚Äôve ended the year on. Ashley Poston‚Äôs pulled off another masterpiece, chock-full of lovable characters and lush imagery.

With all of Poston‚Äôs novels, what shines the most is usually the characters; I‚Äôm delighted to say that Among the Beasts & Briars was no exception! Cerys was such a lovable heroine. I‚Äôm always drawn to and relate to characters who don‚Äôt possess the typical qualities of traditional heroes/heroines‚Äìthey‚Äôd rather stay on the sidelines, aren‚Äôt quite so brave, and are unwillingly forced into strange situations. Like Aurora Rising, I really resonated with the message that you don‚Äôt have to be brave or be from a noble background to be the hero of your own story, and Cerys exemplifies that theme in its fullest.

And I can‚Äôt talk about characters without talking about Fox! He was such a delightful character, and I loved his development as he grappled with his transformation. There‚Äôs no shortage of interesting details in his POV of the shifts between his fox form and the unintentional human form, and he and Cerys had the best chemistry. Vala was also wonderful, and they made for a perfect trio of fantasy misfits. I won‚Äôt spoil anything, but Seren was one of my favorites too‚ÄìREDEMPTION ARCS DONE RIGHT, PEOPLE!

I also loved the fantasy world of Aloriya and the woods. Poston‚Äôs prose makes for so much lush imagery, making for a world that‚Äôs as lived-in as it is fantastical. My favorite aspect was absolutely the Woodcurse‚Äìthere was clearly so much time spent creating the mythology around it, and it was simultaneously fascinating and creepy. And Hellboy made me a sucker for all sorts of spooky monsters, and everything that got swallowed by the Woodcurse just made the paranormal part of my heart so happy.

As with most of Poston‚Äôs novels, Among the Beasts & Briars was reasonably dark, but at its heart, it had such a resonant warmth to it, a glimmer of hope and joy no matter what. With every novel she writes, it clearly shines through how much she loves crafting stories, and it shines through on every page.

All in all, a fresh and unique addition to Poston‚Äôs pantheon of masterful literature. 5 stars!

Among the Beasts & Briars is likely a standalone, but Poston is also the author of the Heart of Iron duology (Heart of Iron and Soul of Stars) and the Once Upon a Con series (Geekerella, The Princess and the Fangirl, and Bookish and the Beast).

Schitt‚Äôs Creek Book Tag

Happy Saturday, bibliophiles, and more importantly, HAPPY NEW YEAR! üéÜ

This tag‚Äôs been *patiently* waiting in a little sticky note on my computer since the beginning of quarantine, so I figured that it would be good to start the year off with a cute book tag. I watched most of Schitt‚Äôs Creek in 2019, but I finished up the last season at the very beginning of quarantine, and it‚Äôs so consistently funny and feel-good!

I found this tag over at Kayla‚Äôs Wordsmithy, and the tag was originally created by Julie @ Pages and Pens and Aimee Reads over on Booktube.

Let‚Äôs begin, shall we?

SCHITT‚ÄôS CREEK BOOK TAG

JOHNNY ROSE: An uplifting book with a good message

My first thought was This Time Will Be Different‚Äîa beautiful tale of resistance, friendship and family. (Plus, that cover‚Ä¶)

MOIRA ROSE: An over-the-top character you can‚Äôt help but love

Jax from Heart of Iron steals the show in both books in the duology‚Äìno shortage of witty quips and HEAPS of sass. He‚Äôs the best.

DAVID ROSE: A book that represents your aesthetic

Tillie Walden‚Äôs On a Sunbeam perfectly fits the bill for this prompt‚Äìa quiet, atmospheric sort of space opera with an interstellar romance woven in.

ALEXIS ROSE: Best character growth/arc

I recently finished Among the Beasts and Briars (which was PHENOMENAL, by the way), and I loved Fox‚Äôs growth throughout the book. I guess being accidentally transformed into a human against one‚Äôs will just does that to the brain.

STEVIE BUDD: A book with a favorite ride or die friendship/group

I love all of the chaotic space misfits in Ann Aguirre and Rachel Caine‚Äôs Honors trilogy, especially in book 3, Honor Lost. They‚Äôre all just so distinct in personality and bounce off each other so well, and they‚Äôre all just so sweet together.

TED MULLENS: Favorite book with an animal on the cover

Definitely not my favorite book, per se, but The Storm Crow has quite a few animals on the cover.

PATRICK BREWER: Ideal love interest

Aurora Burning. One word: Kal.

COMMUNITY SERVICE: A book you read for school/buddy read/readathon challenge you had low expectations for but ended up being amazing

I read All Out of Pretty for my school‚Äôs book club a few years ago, and it blew me away! Difficult to read, for sure, but raw and powerful. I‚Äôd highly recommend it.

‚ÄúEWW, DAVID!‚Äù: A book you DNF‚Äôd because the content was too much for you

I wouldn‚Äôt say that Infinity Son was ‚Äútoo much‚Äù for me, per se, but it was just a steaming mess. I just couldn‚Äôt put up with it after about the 25% mark or so.

‚ÄúLOVE THAT JOURNEY FOR ME‚Äù: Best series ender/overall series progression

TRUEL1F3 was my absolute favorite of the Lifelike trilogy, and such an explosive end to a trilogy like no other.

‚ÄúEAT GLASS‚Äù: An author/series you broke up with

I got through the first four books in the Shatter Me series (definitely hit-or-miss, but book four was great), but then Defy Me came along with all these flat-out RIDICULOUS twists that made no sense at all, so I gave up.

‚ÄúVERY UNINTERESTED IN THAT OPINON‚Äù: A popular opinion that you disagree with

Alright, let me just say it out front: I did NOT enjoy The Cruel Prince. The worldbuilding was great and I liked the little illustrations, but none of the characters were likable. At all. And Jude and Cardan‚Äôs relationship is all kinds of toxic. (HOW AND WHY DO SO MANY PEOPLE LIKE HIM?)

I TAG ANYONE WHO WANTS TO PARTICIPATE! And if you haven‚Äôt watched Schitt‚Äôs Creek yet, I highly recommend it!

‚ÄúIf I don‚Äôt come back, I‚Äôm dead or in jail.‚Äù (Fargo: Year 4 review)

Happy Friday, bibliophiles! I suppose that the bibliophile greeting doesn‚Äôt *quite* fit for this post, but hey, you probably followed this blog for books, right? Today, we‚Äôve got something a little bit different‚Äìbut at least I kept my promise, didn‚Äôt I? I hinted at doing a review for at least a week prior to today‚Ä¶

At the beginning of quarantine, my brother and my parents had just started binging Fargo. So like so many of us have done with different shows in the last 6 months, I starting doing some serious binge-watching. I‚Äôd already been exposed to Noah Hawley‚Äôs masterful storytelling through Legion, but Fargo never ceased to wow me. I forgot about it for a few months after finishing up season 3, and then the trailer for season 4 came out in September. I didn‚Äôt see it coming, but little did I know that this newest season would be my favorite yet!

Here‚Äôs the special thing about Fargo: each season follows a plot that, chances are, you‚Äôve seen before: murder mysteries in small towns, sibling rivalries escalated to astronomical proportions, dysfunctional crime families; this season, in particular, centers around the politics of rivaling Italian and African-American gangs in 1950s Kansas City, and a mortician‚Äôs family who unwillingly gets caught up in the action. But every season, without fail, Noah Hawley spins it into something that you‚Äôve never seen before, be it with the characters, the cinematography, and the plot twists (and there‚Äôs a LOT of plot twists). Fargo is all about the unexpected, and season 4 brings the factor of the unknown and unseen up to levels that I haven‚Äôt seen since‚Ä¶well, I guess that season 3 ending‚Ä¶(no spoilers.)

And maybe I‚Äôm biased for this one. October was one of the hardest months I‚Äôve had in quite a while, and Fargo was, without a doubt, one of the things that kept me going through it. As the season came out, my days started to revolve around the Monday nights that would inevitably bring another episode to fuel me with enough dopamine to keep me going through the rest of the week. But I genuinely believe that this show embodies what storytelling should be‚Äìwhat good TV should be, really. And this season has truly cemented Fargo as my favorite show. (And considering that I don‚Äôt readily jump for murder mysteries/historical fiction, that‚Äôs definitely saying something. That‚Äôs just the power of Noah Hawley, folks‚Ä¶)

Now, TREAD LIGHTLY! This review may contain some minor spoilers, but for your benefit, I‚Äôll try to keep it light on them. But even so, be warned‚Ä¶

I‚Ä¶can‚Äôt really find anything major that I didn‚Äôt like about this season, so consider this review a breakdown of most everything that I loved.

THE GREAT:

Characters/casting/acting: With every Fargo season, there‚Äôs no shortage of complex characters and masterful actors (for previous seasons, see: Martin Freeman, Bokeem Woodbine, Jean Smart, Ewan McGregor, David Thewlis, Mary Elizabeth Winstead, etc.), but season 4 in particular had them in no short supply. I loved all of the (HUGE) main cast and many of the supporting characters, but for one reason or another, this is the first season where I‚Äôve gotten really attached to more than one character. And considering that Fargo is one of those shows that 75%-80% of the main cast is killed off by the time the finale rolls around, it‚Ä¶didn‚Äôt go over well with my emotions. But in all seriousness, THESE CHARACTERS!

Let me just digress to talk about my three favorites in this season:

Doctor Senator (Glynn Turman): let‚Äôs be honest, what‚Äôs not to like? He consistently has some of the best lines/general dialogue in this season, he‚Äôs strategic, he‚Äôs clever, and he‚Äôs instantly likable. I‚Äôll get more in depth on the morally gray theme of the whole season later on in the review, but leave it to Fargo to make us AGGRESSIVELY sympathize with all manner of mobsters and criminals‚Ä¶anyways, this guy‚Äôs the best.

Ethelrida Smutny (E‚Äômyri Crutchfield): LOVE HER! She‚Äôs one of the few characters in this season who‚Äôs morally right and seeks to do the right thing, and she is such a lovable character in every way. She‚Äôs frequently underestimated by most of the adults in this season, but she shows herself to not only be smart‚Äìsmarter than them, in some cases‚Äì, but compassionate and determined to do the right thing. The world needs more people like Ethelrida.

And last but most definitely not least‚Ä¶

Patrick ‚ÄúRabbi‚Äù Milligan (Ben Whishaw): [SCREAMS AND CRIES INTO THE VOID]

Out of the three I just mentioned, he‚Äôs absolutely my favorite. He‚Äôs endured so much tragedy and trauma over the course of his life, but all he wants is for Satchel to have a better life. Again, no shortage of clever and insightful lines, and objectively one of those characters that just needs a big hug and a mug of hot chocolate. Just‚Ä¶just trust me on that one. You‚Äôll see.

But as far as characters, it doesn‚Äôt stop there. Everybody, from Chris Rock (Loy Cannon) to Jason Schwartzman (Josto Fadda) to Jessie Buckley (Oraetta Mayflower) truly shines in season 4. Each character is distinct, complex, and it was an absolute joy to see all of their stories unfold. (Also, it‚Äôs worth it just to see Jason Schwartzman just SNAP‚Ä¶that scene of him just pretending to hold a gun and just go ‚ÄúHAGAGAGAGAGHGHAGSDHAGHGHGH‚Äù just lives rent-free in my mind now‚Ä¶)

(Plus‚Ä¶THE GAYS WON 2020, EVERYBODY! Can we just talk about how Zelmare and Swanee INVENTED ‚Äúbe gay, do crime?‚Äù)

Whew, that went on for a while. BUT WAIT‚ÄìTHERE‚ÄôS MORE, BECAUSE THIS SHOW IS VERY NEARLY FLAWLESS:

Score and soundtrack: At this point, I think it‚Äôs just impossible for Jeff Russo to ever make a bad score for a movie or a TV show. Besides all of the remixes of the music from previous seasons, I loved all of the new songs. I particularly liked Odis (Jack Huston)‚Äôs theme (somehow it almost sounds like a car alarm? But in a good way) and the Legion-y song with the shootout with Zelmare and Swanee at the train station. And I loved all of the other songs that were slipped in. No spoilers for the context of the Johnny Cash song in the finale, but when I tell you that I SOBBED‚Ä¶

Timely themes: One of the main complaints I‚Äôve seen about this season is that it‚Äôs ‚Äútoo woke,‚Äù (üôÑ) which I think is utterly idiotic. This season‚Äôs set in 1950, but it‚Äôs more timely than ever‚Äìthere‚Äôs discussions of race, police brutality, immigration, and what it means to be an American. And it‚Äôs all handled quite well, I think. One thing I‚Äôve always appreciated about the show as a whole is how it depicts the American police system‚Äìfor the first three seasons, there‚Äôs usually 1-2 cops that actually know what they‚Äôre doing, but they‚Äôre frequently dismissed by a largely unbelieving and sexist police force. This season is the first where we have both of our main cops as largely corrupt, but we still sympathize with one of them (PTSD relating to WWII). Most of the characters are morally gray as well (I mean, most of the main cast are members of separate gangs), and that contrast was also well-done.

That classic, Noah Hawley weirdness: in every season, there‚Äôs at least one episode or plot point that‚Äôs highly out of the ordinary, and lucky for us, we got that in the form of episode 9. Besides having a whole episode of Rabbi and Satchel after not seeing them for two episodes, there‚Äôs an amazing Wizard of Oz theme with the whole episode. I‚Äôll shamelessly admit to thinking about it for a solid WEEK.

All the Coen Brothers references, of course: Treehorn? The Raising Arizona screaming? Everything that I missed? LOADS OF FUN.

All in all, this was a masterful show from start to finish. My favorite season out of the four, by far, although I love them all. I‚Äôm already rewatching the whole season over again‚Ä¶

MY RATING: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ

TW/CW: Graphic violence (mostly gunshot wounds, but there‚Äôs some parts that definitely made me queasy), racism, xenophobia, police brutality, some brief racist/homophobic/ablelist slurs, poisoning, loss of loved ones, alcoholism/substance abuse

Writing Soundtracks: Songs and albums I listen to while I write, and tips for making writing playlists

Happy Wednesday, bibliophiles!

I got a notification this morning, and apparently I‚Äôve had this blog running for‚Ä¶5 years? WHOAAAAA, OKAY, I FORGOT ABOUT THAT

I didn‚Äôt start semi-seriously book blogging until about a year ago, but thank you to everybody who has supported me along the way! (And for those of you who had to witness what this blog was like when I was in middle school‚Ä¶I‚Äôm terribly sorry for the horrors you experienced.)

ANYWAY, I figured I should start doing writing-related posts more frequently, so here‚Äôs my first(ish?) stab at it.

Many members of the writing community use music in a number of ways in the process of creating their WIP, be it picking specific songs or albums to listen to while writing, or creating book or character playlists. Music is an integral part of my life, and I‚Äôve managed to weave it into my writing life as well. I always listen to music when I write, so I thought that I would first share some songs, albums, and scores that I like the most to get me writing my WIPs.

INSTRUMENTAL SCORES

I think there‚Äôs been several studies about how instrumental scores help with studying, but for a lot of people, music without lyrics is helpful to focus on their writing, and is less distracting than music with lyrics. I use a mix of music with and without lyrics in writing, but for those of you who are strictly instrumental, here are some of my favorite albums‚Äìmostly film scores, mind you‚Äìthat I use when writing:

Hellboy II: The Golden Army original score‚ÄìDanny Elfman

Yes, yes, I know I blab about this masterpiece quite a lot, but hey, it‚Äôs Danny Elfman doing the score‚Äìwhat‚Äôs not to like? The score ranges from whimsically spooky to action-packed to tear-jerking, so it‚Äôs perfect for writing scenes of all kinds.

Radiohead for Solo Piano‚ÄìJosh Cohen

Even if you aren‚Äôt familiar with Radiohead, this is a spectacular collection of their pieces adapted into instrumental, piano form. I particularly like ‚ÄúMotion Picture Soundtrack‚Äù and ‚ÄúBlack Star.‚Äù

Watchmen original score‚ÄìTrent Reznor and Atticus Ross

Much of this one is electronic, but with a wide range of moods; either way, it‚Äôs always catchy, and perfectly cinematic. Also, there‚Äôs a gorgeous instrumental cover of David Bowie‚Äôs ‚ÄúLife On Mars?‚Äù, so of course I‚Äôd recommend it.

Anything by Jeff Russo, really

Russo has such a wide range, composition-wise, and every single score I‚Äôve come across by him is nothing short of stellar. Some of my favorites include his scores for Legion (FX), and The Umbrella Academy (Netflix), but he‚Äôs also scored everything from Cursed to Lucy in the Sky and Fargo (the TV show)

NON-INSTRUMENTAL SONGS AND ALBUMS

I cram loads of music onto my writing playlists, but there‚Äôs several particular songs and albums that get me more focused/motivated/immersed in my writing than others, so here goes nothing‚Ä¶

Kid A‚ÄìRadiohead

Besides the fact that one of my WIPs features a character who is obsessed with this album, the sheer range of emotion in this album is stunning. Though it‚Äôs chiefly electronic, I‚Äôve used these songs from everything from battle scenes to a funeral scene.

Recommended tracks:

‚ÄúMotion Picture Soundtrack‚Äù

‚ÄúEverything In Its Right Place‚Äù

‚ÄúIdioteque‚Äù

Bury Me at Makeout Creek‚ÄìMitski

Another very emotional album, this one‚Äôs always great for writing scenes associated with any form of love, whether it‚Äôs the promise of it, being in the throes of it, or being apart from it. Then again, you‚Äôre talking to somebody who has had zero (0) experience with any sort of relationships, so take this as you will.

Recommended tracks:

‚ÄúFirst Love/Late Spring‚Äù

‚ÄúFrancis Forever‚Äù

‚ÄúCarry Me Out‚Äù

Yankee Hotel Foxtrot‚ÄìWilco

Apparently they called this album ‚Äúthe American Kid A‚Äù when it came out, so‚Ä¶did I cheat and put Kid A on here twice? If so, I don‚Äôt regret it.

Hello again, bibliophiles!

I don‚Äôt do many reviews of movies and TV shows here, but I figured that I would pour out some thoughts for this one. After reading Thomas Wheeler and Frank Miller‚Äôs Cursed back in April (and loving it), I figured that I would give the Netflix adaptation a try, since I didn‚Äôt have much else to watch save for It‚Äôs Always Sunny in Philadelphia (which I‚Äôm steadily binging at the moment). I finished the show in about a week, and overall, I liked it‚Äìfor the most part, a faithful adaptation, but at times, a forgettable one. I don‚Äôt regret watching it, but it‚Äôs nowhere near my favorite show.

In summary: Cursed is a 10-episode adaptation of Wheeler and Miller‚Äôs 2019 novel, a retelling of Arthurian legend before King Arthur pulled the sword from the stone. It follows Nimue (Katherine Langford), a Fey girl whose home has just been burned down by the Red Paladins, an army of monks bent on purging the Fey from Europe. Her mother‚Äôs dying wish was for her to deliver the Sword of Power to Merlin (Gustaf Skarsg√•rd), and Nimue, fueled by anger at the slaughter of her family and people, sets off to find the famed wizard. Joining forces with Arthur (Devon Terrell), she goes in search of Merlin, only to discover that the sword that she wields may have a darker power than she could have ever imagined.

Alright, folks‚Ä¶below, I‚Äôll break down what I liked and didn‚Äôt like, so be prepared for quite a bit of rambling! This review/breakdown may contain some spoilers, so be warned.

THE GREAT:

The opening title sequence and transitions: Absolutely GORGEOUS. The watercolor style was so detailed and beautiful, and it meshed so well with the general mood of the show.

The instrumental score: I‚Äôll say it once and I‚Äôll say it again: Jeff Russo can do no wrong. Though this score isn‚Äôt as notable as the ones he did for TV shows like FX‚Äôs Legion or Netflix‚Äôs The Umbrella Academy, it was certainly a masterfully composed score, especially in the opening theme and some of the songs from the final two episodes.

The sets/filming locations: Every single location that Cursed was filmed in was such a joy to take in. The forest setting made for countless beautiful shots, and even the more fabricated ones, especially in the Fey refugee camp of Nemos, did volumes in immersing the viewer into the story.

Cast diversity: Kudos to Netflix for casting a variety of actors from all different backgrounds, from the protagonists to the side characters, for the show! There‚Äôs quite a few POC characters both at the forefront (ex. Arthur and Morgana) and in the background, so that was always good to see. There was some LGBTQ+ representation as well, which I‚Äôve been going back and forth about. Morgana, one of the protagonists, is in a sapphic relationship with Celia, but in the first few episodes, Celia is killed when their nunnery burns down. She appears in later episodes, but as an‚Ä¶undead puppet of a spider demon. It‚Äôs dangerously close to the horrific ‚Äúbury your gays‚Äù trope, but‚Ä¶yeah, I don‚Äôt know. On one hand, it‚Äôs set in Medieval Europe, and in a nunnery, no less, so the relationship likely wouldn‚Äôt have ended well even if it hadn‚Äôt burned down. On the other, Celia didn‚Äôt have to be killed off/resurrected for Morgana to have character development‚ÄìCelia could have run off with her, and there still could have been tension there if she had joined her, Nimue, Arthur, and the rest. I‚Äôm still unsure about it, but at least they‚Ä¶tried. And I think there were a few LGBTQ+ couples present in the Fey camp in the background.

Faithfulness to the source material: For the most part, the Netflix adaptation followed the book closely, which was great to see! There‚Äôs a few tweaked details, but they didn‚Äôt bother me much at all.

Now, some of the characters/performances that I liked:

Arthur and Morgana: As brother and sister, they didn‚Äôt have the best chemistry, but individually, both their performances were good! Arthur was simultaneously bumbling and steadfast, just like I imagined him in the book. Morgana was similarly endearing, and they way that the show ended, I‚Äôm interested in seeing how they *might* continue her arc.

Merlin: A lot of the criticism that the book got was about Merlin, specifically about how they had massacred his character, making him a more arrogant man, and more than a bit of a drunkard. But even though I love Arthurian legend as much as the next person, I understood the change‚ÄìCursed is supposed to be a prequel to the events of these legends, and it would make sense for Merlin to be a younger, more disillusioned character, before he became the wise mentor figure that we know and love. Skarsg√•rd‚Äôs performance was well-translated from the book, and I liked following his character.

Uther Pendragon: He‚Äôs exactly the kind of character that you love to hate. Pendragon was the perfect, whiny and overtly arrogant and hotheaded king to contrast with the other characters.

The Red Paladins: Though Sister Iris was a bit underused, the Red Paladins are just as chilling as they appear in the novel.

THE NOT-SO-GREAT:

‚Ä¶Nimue: I liked her character in the book, but Langford‚Äôs acting just felt‚Ä¶so flat, so lacking in emotion. I wanted to root for her, but there was such a lack of heart in the character that I could barely muster up any emotion.

The romance: They had this in the book as well, but I wasn‚Äôt as much of a fan of it there, either. It felt like it was needlessly shoehorned in to appease the Teen‚Ñ¢Ô∏è audience.

The gratuitous violence: Again, I suppose this means that it was faithful to the books, because the book was very violent, but it was definitely a bit much. Some of it felt like it was only added in for the shock value, and could have been cut out in the long run. Also, the effect of the blood splattering onto the camera lens works well in present day/more futuristic media, but it took away from the Medieval European setting.

The subplots: At least they got tied up at the end (somewhat), but they didn‚Äôt contribute to the story. Pym‚Äôs whole arc with the Red Spear felt wholly unnecessary, and just fan service that assumed that everyone would appreciate that they kept their comic relief character alive and giving her a romantic arc. Most of the Red Spear characters bugged me as well (especially the captain). The subplot with Morgana, Celia, and the spider demon was a little bit better, but it didn‚Äôt do much to the story, other than giving the allusion that Morgana might become more powerful than Nimue herself.

That awful song at the end of episode 9: OH GOD. OHHHH GOD. NOPE. Aside from being blatantly manufactured to be put in the show, it again took me out of the setting. I mean, it‚Äôs not like a medieval sea shanty would have worked any better for the scene, but I found myself rolling my eyes sky-high.

The acting: Even though I listed some of the good performances above, most of them were‚Ä¶good, but forgettable. Other than the characters listed, nobody quite stood out for me (save for Sister Iris). Decent, but nothing that blew me away.

Overall, Cursed wasn‚Äôt spectacular, but I don‚Äôt regret watching it. The filming locations, score, and transitions were gorgeous, and it mostly stayed true to the source material, but it was dragged down by a few unnecessary subplots and forgettable acting. I‚Äôd give it a solid 3/5.

Would I recommend it? I suppose I would. For all you fantasy lovers and fans of the original novel who don‚Äôt have much else to watch, I‚Äôd encourage you to give it a watch. As long as you have the stomach for quite a lot of violence, though.
